awd_titl_txt: CAREER:  Interactions between Stress and Attention Circuits: Investigating Corticotropin Releasing Factor Modulation of the Basal Forebrain
awd_abstract_narration:
It is easy to think of examples of how stressful life events can impair cognition. Of interest to the principal investigator of this project is the ability of stress to impair sustained attention, the process of monitoring situations for rare and unpredictably occurring events. Adequately sustaining attention is critical for accurately performing more complex cognitive tasks.  Therefore, disruptions in sustained attention as a result of stress can lead to widespread cognitive impairments. Surprisingly, the neurobiological mechanisms that underlie the effect of stress on this type of attention are unknown. This project addresses this gap in knowledge by using behavioral, neuroanatomical, and molecular approaches to test how a specific stress-related chemical signal, corticotropin releasing factor, regulates the brain circuitry required for sustained attention in male and female rats. The results from this research will greatly advance our understanding of the interactions between the brain systems involved in stress and attention. These findings thereby may lay the groundwork for the development of strategies aimed at improving cognition during stressful events. In addition to the scientific work, this project includes an education plan designed to improve student learning outcomes for Temple University's diverse undergraduate population and create public resources for improving the teaching of college courses in the "flipped-classroom" format, in which students first learn new material outside of class and then use class time to work on exercises with classmates and the instructor.

Studies have examined how stress modulates learning, the neurobiological mechanisms by which stress modulates attention remain underexplored. Recently, the principal investigator of this project demonstrated that sustained attention is disrupted by central infusions of the stress-related neuropeptide, corticotropin releasing factor (CRF) in male and female rats. Sustained attention is known to be mediated by the basal forebrain.  Therefore, this project examines how CRF regulates the basal forebrain from the systems to the molecular levels. Aim 1 is to test the hypothesis that CRF directly modulates the basal forebrain to disrupt sustained attention by combining pharmacological manipulations and a well-validated attention task. Aim 2 is to uncover the circuitry by which CRF can impact basal forebrain neurons by using retrograde tracing, cell-type specific markers, and measures of neuronal activation. Aim 3 is to identify molecular changes induced by CRF in cholinergic basal forebrain neurons by using Fluorescent Activated Cell Sorting in combination with next generation sequencing. The findings will improve our fundamental understanding of how stress affects cognition. The rich sequencing data resulting from this work is an important resource for researchers studying attention circuits, and is to be made publicly available for use by other investigators. The project's education plan is designed to improve the flipped-classroom format by developing special assignments that emphasize cognitive and metacognitive techniques to promote active engagement with the out-of-class material. These assignments are made available through public media and their efficacy is examined experimentally.  The insights gained from the educational plan are to be published in education journals.

por.por_cntn:
This NSF grant aimed to determine the neurobiological mechanisms by which stress modulates sustained attention, the ability to continuously detect intermittent and unpredictable events. First, we modified a rat sustained attention task to work with touchscreen operant chambers, which are popular given their flexibility to run multiple cognitive tasks. This program is now available as resource for the research community. Next, we focused on a stress neuropeptide, corticotropin releasing factor (CRF), which has receptors (so can act) in attention circuits. We found that CRF in the basal forebrain (BF) attention circuit disrupts aspects of attentional performance. CRF in this region also alters glutamate synthesis, suggesting a mechanism by which the impaired attention occurs. Additional studies found that exposure to variable stress (VS) impairs attention in both male and female rats. We developed a new technique to visualize cholinergic BF neurons and found that VS alters the morphology of their dendrites, which could affect how inputs to these neurons are processed. Then, we used RNA sequencing to determine how VS altered the transcriptome of the BF. The most upregulated gene by VS was Dual Specificity Phosphatase 1 (Dusp1). DUSP1 is a stress-inducible signaling protein that can regulate dendritic morphology. Thus, increases in DUSP1 may contribute to the changes in cholinergic dendrite morphology following VS, which could represent a novel mechanism mediating stress-induced attentional deficits. In addition to studies on attention, we also found that CRF in a different cholinergic brain region, the medial septum, impairs spatial memory and that changes in the postnatal environment affect later cognitive performance. The results from these projects have been disseminated in over 20 publications and presented to the scientific community via conferences and the lay community via podcasts, a public lecture at the University of Pennsylvania, and an article in Scientific American Mind.

This grant has also provided many training opportunities: over 20 trainees helped with the research component of the grant. Of the trainees who have been in my laboratory 68% are female and 32% are from an underrepresented group (URMs as defined by NSF, LGBTQIA+, and/or registered disability). In addition to students who directly worked on the project, the education goals of this grant improved learning outcomes for undergraduate students at Temple University. I developed special assignments to promote cognitive and metacognitive skills to enhance the out-of-class learning that takes place in the flipped classroom, a format that I use for two undergraduate courses. Additionally, the findings from the research studies in this proposal were integrated into lectures to expose undergraduate students to the latest research findings and teach them about research techniques. In addition, I developed the BRIDGE (Building Research Independence by Developing Goals and Hands-on Experiences) program, which targets neuroscience and psychology majors who are from underrepresented populations and have not had the opportunity for research experience prior to their last (typically senior) year of college. BRIDGE provides scholars with paid summer research experience, individualized mentoring, and networking and professional development opportunities. We have had 10 BRIDGE scholars complete the program and another 11 are selected for this summer. Finally, this grant received a supplement for a collaborative experiment with Dr. Elizabeth Becker and her laboratory, which is at a primarily undergraduate institution. Her students were trained in several new approaches by my staff and accessed equipment in my laboratory, which they would not normally use.

The studies conducted in the proposal have implications for improving health. Although the studies themselves focused on basic research questions, the results of the proposal may eventually be translated into broader applications. For example, by identifying the neurobiological mechanisms by which stress alters sustained attention, drugs that target these mechanisms may be developed. Such compounds could be used to improve attention in disorders such as attention deficit hyperactivity disorder, as well as to treat stress-related disorders (e.g., PTSD), which are characterized by attentional disruptions. Data from this project may lead to new interventions that ultimately help multiple populations of people cope with stress and stress-related impairments.
